question: In a 5 year old child, instead of the physiological splitting of second hea sound, expected only during inspiration, a wide and a fixed split of S2 is heard, both during inspiration, as well as expiration. Condition associated with this is?
exp: WIDE FIXED SPLIT OF S2 IS SEEN IN: ASD Right Bundle Branch Block TAPVC WIDE VARIABLE SPITTING OF S2 IS SEEN IN: Pulmonic stenosis VSD Mitral regurgitation

question: Holt-Oram syndrome is characterized by?
exp: Holt-Oram syndrome: - Autosomal dominant disorder - Characterized by - skeletal abnormalities of hands and arms like: Hypoplastic/ absent thumbs, radii Triphalangism Phocomelia - Cardiac anomalies ASD 1st degree hea block TRIPHALANGISM phacomelia

question: A child with VSD develops the following findings. There is no history of fever. What is the probable cause of these findings?
exp: --> Clubbing & cyanosis in a child with VSD, with no history of fever, is suggestive of Eisenmenger syndrome. --> EISENMENGER SYNDROME: Any untreated congenital cardiac defect with intracardiac communication that leads to pulmonary hypeension, reversal of flow , cyanosis. --> VSD + FEVER + CLUBBING --> suggestive of INFECTIVE ENDOCARDITIS --> CYANOTIC SPELL/ TET SPELL: Episodic central cyanosis due to total occlusion of right ventricle outflow in a patient with a congenital hea disease, such as Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). --> PATENT DUCTUS AERIOSUS: Persistence of connection b/w pulmonary aery & aoa even after bih.

question: Large ventricular septal defect in a child leads to all of the following EXCEPT?
exp: Complications of large VSD: Cardiac failure - MC; occurs in early infancy Infective endocarditis - occurs at any age Pulmonary hypeension (Eisenmenger syndrome). Note:- Cyanotic spell is usually a feature of TOF

question: In septum primum type of ASD overburden occurs in which chamber?
exp: - In ASD (ostium primum as well as secundum) overload of Right atrium and right ventricle occurs due to left to right shunting of blood. - Left atrium & Left ventricle enlargement - VSD, PDA - Left atrium enlargement - Mitral stenosis

question: True statement about ductus aeriosus is:
exp: IMPOANT POINTS ABOUT DUCTUS AERIOSUS: - Physiological closure: occurs almost immediately after bih by contraction of muscular wall - Anatomic closure: occurs by proliferation of intima in 10-21 days after bih - After obliteration, it forms ligamentum aeriosum. - Murmur due to PDA - Continuous machinery murmur. - Ductus aeriosus is kept open with the help of prostaglandins in ductus dependent conditions Note : Prostaglandin inhibitors are used to close the ductus aeriosus. Intravenous (IV) indomethacin or ibuprofen is used to treat patent ductus aeriosus (PDA) in premature infants.
opa: It undergoes anatomic closure within 24 hours of bih
opb: It connects aoa with pulmonary vein
opc: It is induced to close by high levels of prostaglandins
opd: May cause a machinery murmur by its patency

question: Most common type of ASD?
exp: Types of ASD: Name Remarks Ostium secundum Located in the central poion of atrial septum; Most common type of ASD Ostium primum Located at lower pa of the atrial septum Sinus venosus defect Located at junction of superior vena cava and right atrium Coronary sinus defect Refers to unroofed coronary sinus which is a rare communication between the coronary sinus and the left atrium

question: A 4 year old child had cyanosis only involving the lower limbs, but not involving the upper limbs. Which of the following could be a possible underlying cause for differential cyanosis?
exp: --> Differential cyanosis is seen in PDA with reversal of shunt --> Differential cyanosis: No cyanosis in upper limbs --> as oxygenated blood goes there. Cyanosis in lower limbs --> d/t mixing of oxygenated blood with deoxygenated blood. PATENT DUCTUS AERIOSUS : --> Failure of closure of Ductus aeriosus after bih , resulting in persistent connection b/w aoa & pulmonary aery. --> Hypoxia & prematurity predispose to PDA --> AUSCULTATION --> Continuous machinery murmur is seen --> DOC for medical closure of PDA in preterm neonate --> PG Inhibitor --> Normally PDA is acyanotic hea disease but with reversal of shunt, differential cyanosis is seen.

question: ASD is associated with all EXCEPT:
exp: - Infective endocarditis is usually not seen in ASD, as the gradient between right and left atria is very small. ATRIAL SEPTAL DEFECT : - Connection b/w 2 atria - 2 types: Ostium primum Ostium secundum - Auscultatory findings: Wide, fixed split of S2 Large ASD - Diastolic murmur in tricuspid area; Ejection systolic murmur in pulmonary area are seen - Assessment of severity: Severity is directly propoional to intensity of murmurs & hea size - Complications: Pulmonary hypeension - by 2nd/ 3rd decade Atrial arrythmias Hea failure - in late adulthood stroke - Treatment: Small defects - - observation, as spontaneous closure is seen in most cases Others - surgical closure of defect EXTRA EDGE: Infective endocarditis is most commonly associated with VSD Congenital rubella syndrome is least commonly associated with ASD

question: True about 'Tetralogy of Fallot' (TOF) are all of the following EXCEPT?
exp: TETRALOGY OF FALLOT: --> MC congenital cyanotic hea disease in children --> Contain 4 COMPONENTS: 1. Large, unrestricted VSD 2. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis 3. Overriding aoa 4. Right ventricular hyperophy --> CLINICAL FEATURES: Cyanosis Clubbing Polycythemia Cyanotic spells Hea failure is not seen in TOF, unless it is complicated by Anemia /Infective endocarditis /Myocarditis / Systemic hypeension Severity of cyanosis is directly propoional to the severity of pulmonary stenosis; while intensity of murmur is inversly propoional to severity of pulmonary stenosis During cyanotic spell, murmur decreases or becomes absent -Ostium primum type ASD: It is situated in the lower poion of atrial septum and overlies mitral and tricuspid valves. Left axis detion is seen in ostium primum ASD due to RV conduction defect. - Ostium secundum is most common type of ASD - SYNDROMES ASSOCIATED WITH ASD 1. Pierre Robin Sequence 2. TAR Syndrome 3. Fetal Alcohol syndrome 4. Ehler Danlos Syndrome 5. Down Syndrome 6. Holt-Oram syndrome 7. Ellis van Creveld Syndrome 8. Rubinstein Taybi syndrome
opa: It is the most common congenital cyanotic hea disease in children
opb: Severity of disease depends on the severity of pulmonary stenosis
opc: Atrial septal defect is one of the components of TOF
opd: Boot shaped hea is seen on chest X ray

question: A child presented at 10 weeks with recurrent episode of pneumonia and failure to thrive. X-ray show cardiomegaly & pulmonary plethora diagnosis?
exp: - Features given in the question are suggestive of VSD VENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECT : - Communication b/w 2 ventricles of hea - 90% are located in membranous pa of ventricular septum with variable extension into muscular septum. - Clinical features: Usually presents at 6-10 weeks of age Recurrent episodes of pneumonia Hea failure Failure to thrive X-ray showing cardiomegaly & pulmonary plethora -->MC congenital hea disease in children--> VSD -->MC congenital acyanotic hea disease in children--> VSD -->MC congenital hea diseases affected by infective endocarditis in children--> VSD
